text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 21.7.3, Business Tax Returns and Non-Master File Accounts, Unemployment Taxes.
This IRM was revised to reﬂect the following changes:

IRM Subsection Description IRM 21.7.3.4.10(2) Updated table with 2021 credit reduction data. IPU 21U1262 issued 11-16-2021. Exhibit 21.7.3-1 Updated table with the 2021 state unemployment insurance taxable wage base. IPU 21U1262 issued 11-16-2021. Editorial-type changes Editorial changes have been made throughout the IRM for clarity.

) This section contains information on Business Master File (BMF) accounts related to the Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA). and (

) Purpose: The procedures in this IRM are a translation of a variety of legal administrative authorities into practical guidance for the Customer Service resentatives and Tax Examining Assistants who work taxpayer inquiries (in- person, paper, and phone) and tax account issues regarding taxes. (
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM are Customer Service tives and Tax Examining Assistants who work unemployment tax program inquiries. (
) Policy Owner: The policy owner is the Director, Accounts Management, and Investment Division. (
) Program Owner: The program owner is Wage and Investment, Accounts agement, Policy and Procedures BMF. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are Wage and (W&I), Small Business Self Employed (SBSE), and Large Business and national (LB&I). (

) Program Goals: The BMF sites strive to maintain integrity, quality, and lence in the service provided taxpayers by making every effort to achieve a high customer accuracy and efficiency rate. The unemployment tax goals are included with other BMF inventory production goals published in annual Accounts Management Program Letter. (

) The Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) provides for cooperation states and the federal government in the establishment and administration unemployment insurance. Unemployment insurance is a system which provides beneﬁts for unemployed workers. Unemployment taxes, which are paid to federal and state governments by covered employers, subsidize administered unemployment insurance programs and create a fund that is used to pay unemployment beneﬁts to unemployed workers. (

) Employees in the Accounts Management (AM) and Field Assistance (FA) nizations respond to taxpayer inquiries (in-person, phone, and paper) as as claims, certain applications, internal requests, and transcripts related to Form
, Employer’s Annual Federal Unemployment (FUTA) Tax Return. (
) In addition to all official guidance on general tax matters, the administration the unemployment tax discussed in this IRM is based primarily on tax law visions found under U.S. Code, Title
, Internal Revenue Code, Subtitle Chapter
, Federal Unemployment Tax Act (Section
through Section
), and related regulations, treasury decisions, revenue procedures, revenue rulings, notices, tax forms and instructions, and publications. (

) The Director of Accounts Management has oversight responsibility for this (

) Accounts Management Policy and Procedures BMF (PPB) has for this IRM content which issues guidance to employees who assist with resolving account issues and processing amended returns. These dures include Internal Data Retrieval System (IDRS) input instructions. This IRM is published on an annual basis. (
) Site management officials are responsible for providing daily program through quality review, training, timely communication of procedural within the program, and elevation of guidance gaps. (
) Employees working the program are responsible for following IRM completing assigned training, reviewing updates during read time, and reporting guidance gaps to management. (

) Program management and review is essential for achieving the program identiﬁed in the Accounts Management Program Letter. The program ness is determined by employees successfully using IRM guidance to necessary account actions and duties. The unemployment tax inventory is combined with other BMF inventory streams and randomly selected for Centralized Evaluative Review (CER) and site mangers set the review tion, so the employee receives a balance of phone and paper reviews to an employee’s work assignments. (

) The program monitoring and work reviews are performed for the following reasons: • To make an objective assessment of an employee’s performance on ongoing basis and to ensure that adequate information is available mid-year and annual appraisals • To protect the rights of customers • To identify error trends and training needs (
) Centralized Evaluative Review (CER) conduct quality telephone reviews through Verint and correspondence reviews through the Correspondence Imaging System (CIS). (
) Site managers conduct the following types of reviews: • Inventory Management using the CCA
, IDRS Automated Age Listing (AAL) and CCA
, IDRS Multiple Case Control Listing. listings are available on the Control-D/Web Access server, which login program control. • IDRS Security Reviews Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

21.7.3.1.4 (08-23-2021) Program Management and Review
Taxes

• Performance reviews on effective case and call resolution according IRM guidelines. • Side-by-side non-evaluative reviews for skill development. • Reviews of closed cases for both accuracy and productivity to determine if work is being closed in an efficient and effective • Workload reviews to assess whether the amount of time being spent commensurate with the complexity and type of work. • Reviews of cases currently in process to ensure that inventory is closed according to received date and that cases are not necessarily suspended. (

) The unemployment tax inventory is combined with other BMF inventory streams and subject to Accounts Management enterprise controls. This program is included with all BMF management reviews and operational reviews. (

) Accounts Management uses the Embedded Quality Review Program to closed case work. The Quality Review process provides a method to measure, and improve the quality of work. Quality Review data is used to provide quality statistics for the IRS’s Business Results portion of the Measures, and/or to identify trends, problem areas, training needs, and tunities for improvement. (
) Centralized Quality Review System (CQRS) is operated by the Joint tions Center (JOC) to provide independent quality review services for all product lines. (

) Local reviews are performed to focus attention on program that require im- provement. The local quality reviews are performed by staffs reporting to Quality Assurance Manager, Corrective and Preventative Action System Manager (CPAS), or other units that have quality assurance duties. Local quality reviews are also used for employee development and on-the-job in- struction. (

) Quality Review data is used by management to provide a basis for and improving program effectiveness by identifying: • Defect(s) resulting from site or systemic action(s) or inaction(s) • Driver(s) of customer accuracy • Reason(s) for defect occurrence • Defect trends • Recommendation(s) for corrective action • Training needs (

) The Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) provides for cooperation states and the federal government in the establishment and administration unemployment insurance. Unemployment insurance is a system which provides beneﬁts for unemployed workers. Unemployment taxes, which are paid to federal and state governments by covered employers, subsidize administered unemployment insurance programs and create a fund that is used to pay unemployment beneﬁts to unemployed workers. paid each employee is subject to FUTA tax. The FUTA tax applies to payments such as: • Salaries • Wages

) This section contains procedures for unemployment taxes. Reminder: This section attempts to address situations most frequently Taxes when working unemployment tax issues. The guidance contained in and other applicable IRMs cannot address every possible taxpayer inquiry. In some cases, it may be necessary to consult your lead or manager to determine the appropriate action. Elevate any issue or question that cannot be resolved at the site level or could have wide impact to the appropriate Headquarters analyst with program responsibility. (
) The IRS uses the FUTA Certiﬁcation program to determine whether Form or Schedule H (Form
) reported state payments were paid into the priate state unemployment fund. There are
participating agencies, includes the

states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Program Virgin Islands. Small Business Self Employed (SB/SE) Campus employees certify state payments (credits) using the procedures in IRM Certiﬁcation of State Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) Credits. (

) The FUTA Case Processing (FCP) system is used by the SB/SE FUTA reconcile cases determined to have discrepancies. The state payment data downloaded to the FCP system and the system identiﬁes potential tax increases and decreases. The download to the FCP system is identiﬁed by FUTA Release Year. The October
download is identiﬁed as the FUTA Release
) Discrepancy cases result from the computerized and manual certiﬁcations payments to State Unemployment Insurance Agencies. (

This section attempts to address situations most frequently encountered when working unemployment tax issues. The guidance contained in this and other applicable IRMs cannot address every possible taxpayer inquiry. In some cases, it may be necessary to consult your lead or manager to determine the appropriate action. Elevate any issue or question that cannot be resolved at the site level or could have Service
wide impact to the appropriate Headquarters analyst with program responsibility.

participating agencies, which includes the

states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Small Business Self Employed (SB/SE) Campus Compliance employees certify state payments (credits) using the procedures in IRM Certiﬁcation of State Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) Credits. (

) The FUTA Case Processing (FCP) system is used by the SB/SE FUTA team reconcile cases determined to have discrepancies. The state payment data is downloaded to the FCP system and the system identiﬁes potential tax increases and decreases. The download to the FCP system is identiﬁed by FUTA Release Year. The October
download is identiﬁed as the FUTA Release

The IRS uses the FUTA Certiﬁcation program to determine whether Form 940 or Schedule H (Form 1040) reported state payments were paid into the appro- priate state unemployment fund. There are 53 participating agencies, which includes the 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Small Business Self Employed (SB/SE) Campus Compliance employees certify state payments (credits) using the procedures in IRM 4.19.5, Certiﬁcation of State Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) Credits.

, enacted August

, states the IRS must notify taxpayers in advance that we may contact third parties to help resolve their accounts. Contacts with any office of any governmental entity are exempt except for contacts concerning the taxpayer’s business with the government office contacted, such as the taxpayer’s contracts with or em- ployment by the office. This is a rare occurrence for manual certiﬁcation requests. If the taxpayer is an employee or contractor with the state, review the guidance under IRM
, Notiﬁcation of Third Party Contact, to determine whether to report the third-party contact. (

ﬁlers must complete and ﬁle Schedule A, Multi-State Employer and Credit Reduction Information. The Schedule A is also used to report wages paid in any state subject to credit reduction. See IRM

) The tax liability for multiple state cases is computed the same as single state cases; however, the additional credit is computed for each individual state. IRM

, Additional Credit Computation, for computation procedures. After the tax liability is computed for each individual state, the results are combined into one amount and only one tax item reference code is used to adjust the tax liability. The primary state is used to adjust the tax. IRM
, Item Reference Codes (Form
), provides item reference code determination guidance. (

) The primary state wage item reference code is used for all wages not ated with a credit reduction state. The wages of a credit reduction state always be adjusted for the exact amount of the change. When the credit reduction state wages have been adjusted and there are left-over wages, the left-over wages are adjusted under the primary state wage item reference code. If unable to determine the primary state, adjust the state indicating the highest wages paid. If unable to determine the state with the highest wages paid, adjust the state listed on the address of record. If the primary state, the Internal Revenue Manual

All increases and decreases in tax must have item reference codes showing the tax associated with the state where the adjustment is indicated. a. The tax item reference code amount must equal the TC

X tax adjust- ment. b. The three-digit item reference code for the tax portion of the adjustment is comprised of a “T” followed by the two-digit state code. If adjustment is due to an increase or decrease in wages, an item reference code for wages is also required. The three-digit item reference code for the wage portion is comprised of “W” followed by the two-digit state code. If more than one state is involved, input the adjustment using the primary state. If unable to determine the primary state, adjust the state which the highest wages paid. If unable to determine the state with highest wages paid, adjust the state listed on the address of record. Caution is used if any of the states being amended were a credit reduction state for that par- ticular tax year. In that case, each credit reduction state wage adjustment be input. See IRM
, Multiple State Cases, for an example. If no increase or decrease to tax or wages is made, item reference codes not needed.

cable whenever an amended/supplemental return is ﬁled or when a revised ROFTL schedule is submitted by the taxpayer. The new ROFTL requires a manual recalculation and update of the penalty. If deposits are made late, not made in sufficient amounts, made directly to the IRS (e.g., sending a check with a tax return or paying by credit card), or not made using EFT, a FTD penalty may be imposed on the module. IRM 20.1.4, Failure to Deposit Penalty, provides Form 940 deposit requirements, penalty calculation guidance using Command Code FTDPN, and instructions for using transaction code to assess or adjust a FTD penalty.

Under current law, federally recognized Indian tribal governments (ITG) and their subdivisions, subsidiaries, and wholly-owned business enterprises are exempt from Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) and can elect to partici- pate in a state unemployment fund (SUTA), or in a reimbursement program. The SUTA exemption is an entity-by-entity election. If an election is made, the entity is exempt from FUTA only if it is a full participant in SUTA or in a reim- bursement option with the state, and all SUTA liabilities are fully paid. Reduction States However, the credit is reduced when a state has taken loans from the federal government to meet its state unemployment beneﬁt liabilities and has not repaid these loans within the allowable time frame. A state that has not repaid money it has borrowed from the federal government is called a credit state. The reduction is
